II How escape if we neglect it

46 Central Baptist Church
______________________
ARTICLES OF FAITH
_____________________
I. OF THE SCRIPTURES.
We believe that the Holy Bible was written 
by men divinely inspired, and is a perfect treasure of heavenly instruction: that it has God for 
its author, salvation for its end, and truth without any mixture of error, for its matter; that it
reveals the principles by which God will judge 
us; and therefore is, and shall remain to the end 
of the word, the true centre of Christian union,
and the supreme standard by which all human 
conduct, creeds, and opinions should be tried.
2 Tim. iii. 16, 17. Pro. xxx. 5, 6. Rom. ii. 12. Isa. viii. 20
II. OF THE TRUE GOD
We believe that there is one, and only one, living
and true God, an infinite, intelligent Spirit, whose
name is JEHOVAH, the Maker and Supreme Ruler
of heaven and earth; inexpressibly glorious in holiness, and worthy of all possible honor, confidence,
and love; that in the unity of the Godhead there
are three persons, the Father, the Son, and the
Holy Ghost; equal in every divine perfection,
and executing distinct but harmonious offices in
the great work of redemption.
John iv. 24. Ex xv. II. Matt. xviii. 19. John x. 30.
III. OF THE FALL OF MAN
We believe that the man was created in holiness,
under the law of his Maker; but by voluntary
transgression fell from that holy and happy state;
in consequence of which all mankind are now sinners, not by constraint, but choice; being by nature
utterly void of that holiness required by the law

And these charges he proves

 First, by the admissions of theatrical press writers themselves. And when it is objected "Not these same witnesses testify to much that is excellent & praise worthy on the theater boards - that these citations are disjointed & disconnected utterances without reference to the context" - he replies in the following caustic way: 'I would like to be told how purity on the stage justifies pollution and what effect any "context" can have on "profanity" or "double entendre" or "immodest exposure" or "nauseous twaddle" or "appeals to baser instincts". For instance I have said a Theatrical Critic speaks of a Certain play as exhibiting an "uncalled-for display of feminine

figures which runs through the whole evening, and in some junctures trembles along the verge of the positively shocking." Can any "Context" however chaste and pure, wash out that fondness or palliate that appeal to lust? When a man swears, he swears, doesn't he? He may put reverent speech, alongside his oath, but that "context" does not make it any the less an oath. How long would Christian patronage be given one of our Churches whose officers by any possibility should should prevailingly fill its pulpit with Ingersolls*, even though here and there they should pad the pulpit ministrations with an

 [possibly referring to the agnostic Robert Ingersoll]

Angel Gabriel? And if a Christian man denounced for its gross infidelity the Church, the Christian institution that did this thing, and called upon all Christians never to darken its door, what kind of an answer would it be to say: My dear sir, your assault is indiscriminate - you forget our intermittent Gabriel." This reply seems to me to be thoroughly satisfactory.   The second proof sustaining these charges is the character of the hand bills taken from the four leading theaters of this city for the three months of September, Oct. & Nov - 1881

The following Comparisons are made: At Hooley's 13 Evenings were given to the so called Standard drama (Keene) & 76 Evenings  to trash. At McVicker's 12 Evenings were given to Miss Anderson, 6 to Joe Jefferson, 12 to Denman Thompson, and 48 to trash. At Haverley's 18 Evenings to the Standard drama (McCullough) and 51 to trash. At the Grand Opera, all the 79 Evenings to trash, unless "Patience" or the "Pirates of Penzance" may be otherwise regarded. But to call the stuff thus put on the Chicago Theater boards "trash" is not to tell half the truth. Trash may be clean

Though vapid and shallow it may be an insult to intelligence and an offense to taste, but not an affront to morals. But this trash of the theaters is all three."

The third proof sustaining these charges is the admissions of prominent and reputable actors. Soon after Dr Johnsons first charge was made one of these actors was heard to say - "Would to God I dared to say all I know and feel about this matter. But Johnson is right: only he has not told half the truth."

3  His remedy

 This is not reform - such a thing he claims is impossible, and history has proven it to be true over & over again. The only way to reform the theater is to destroy it. But if it cannot  presently be destroyed it can be denounced - legislated against - and its managers and those who patronise it be put under the ban of social ostracism.

[sentence crossed out:  Managers and those who patronise it under to ban of social ostracism.] 
That it cannot be reformed by the patronage of Chn people - he proves in this specific way.

1. The number of religious people who could be persuaded to attend the theater, and yet who would not tolerate anything indelicate by their presence would be so few as not to have any influence either one way or the other. The masses would still demand the play that appeals to the passions.
2. The facts are 1st that the theater in this City and Country never had the support and encouragement of moral & religious people it now enjoys, and 2nd that the theater was never so bad.

3. The support of the theater by Chn [Christian] men is compromising - It puts the moral and the religious to the support of an institution that is the open and notorious purveyor of indecency and filth.   It does not matter even if Chns select the so called "Clean night" for their patronage. Whom do they patronise? The Theater as an institution. Whom do they support? The management who stands convicted of the crime of debauching the public morals.
4. His manner & method - [sentence crossed out:  (see newspaper beg. of article)]   I have already given you

some idea of Dr. Johnsons manner of meeting his opponents in the quotations which I have made. but to make this more prominent and to illustrate more fully the severity of his attitude toward this institution - let me quote again - from his open letter to the Hon E. C. Larned. "You say I do not deny your two propositions
1. That there is nothing essentially evil in dramatic representations   2  That the taste for them has existed for a very long period. Why should I deny them? Assent goes without saying. But neither will

you deny  1. That there is nothing essentially evil in human nakedness.  2  That the taste for it and for many other things that need not be named is a good deal older than the taste for dramatic Entertainments. Yet you do not need to be told that if we have nude nature we must get back into Eden or go down into Savagery. So it we have the theater we must have a regenerated and sanctified human nature, or we must have more of less of filth on the boards."

14
And who knoweth whether thou art come to the Kingdom for such a time as this.  Esther 4-14

  Here is the record of an Emergency and how it was met - It was the sense of a coming and fearful issue - that pressed itself upon Esthers heart and led her to act for her people. There was no compulsion of outward circumstances on her own part that made her take that bold step. It was the urgency of a claim upon her that could not be met by any other individual. The decree had gone forth. The might of the King's armies and the stability of the Kings commands were pledged to its execution. Her people were condemned to die. The day was

15
fixed. There was no reprieve. No deliverer appeared. The opportunities for an effort in Her behalf were rapidly lessening. Messengers were already speeding Her away to every part of the dominion, bearing the summons of death. New messengers must go just as far to countermand the dread decree. She must speak at once if at all. She ventured and triumphed! Such was the time for which Esther came to the Kingdom - a time of peril! There are similar times connected with the Kingdom of Christ.

16
Emergencies are ever upon us. Not merely concerning thrones and Kingdoms and physical danger - but concerning the souls of men. The decree has gone forth from a just God declaring all men everywhere under the dominion of sin, guilty and condemned. "The Soul that Sinneth it shall die." It is not the wail of a nation, but of a world. The idea of death lies at the basis of all true Christian faith. Sin is a peril as well as a plague. it not, the Bible is a farce. The Eternal life of the Gospel has its fearful counterpart in the Eternal death from which it bids us flee. There can be no Salvation without a lost condition - No heaven without

17
a hell.  Jesus Christ came to save men - How could he, unless they were in peril. Death and live oppose each other throughout the Bible. Ebal had its Gerizim, and Sinai its Calvary  These stand over against each other. Adam and Christ personify these two great ideas. In the one all die, and in the other all are made alive. The whole theory of sin and salvation is expressed in the passage "The wages of sin is death but the gift of God is Eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord."

18
But there are conditions which intensify this peril. The decree which doomed the Jews fixed the limit of their probation. Beyond that they could not pass unless salvation came from another place." Every day lessened the opportunity for their deliverance. There is an appointed limit to the sins of men. The day and hour is written in the dark. No man may know the extent of the divine forbearance. The day of Grace is not necessarily as long as the day of life. For God says, My spirit shall not always strive with man.

19
Here is a line by us unseen
That crosses every path
The hidden boundary between
Gods patience and his wrath.
To pass that limit is to die
To die as if by stealth
It does not quench the beaming eye
Nor pale the glow of health
The conscience may be still as ease
The spirits light and gay
That which is pleasing still may please
And care be thrust away
But on that forehead God has set
Indelibly a mark
Unseen by man, for man as yet
Is blind and in the dark.
Indeed the doomed one's patt? below
May bloom as Eden bloomed

20
He did not, does not, will not know
Or feel that he is doomed.
He feels per chance that all is well
And every fear is calmed
He lives, he dies, he makes us tell?
Not only doomed but damned
O where is that mysterious bourn
By which our path is crossed
Beyond which God himself hath sworn
That he who goes is lost.

Then consider that increase of light adds responsibility. Christ said:  This is the condemnation that light is come into the world

and men loved darkness rather than light. The longer the world

21
stands the more light we have and the more fearful it is to live. The difficulties of faith today are nothing to be compared with what they were in the time of our first parents who saw Christ through the dim light of one prophetic passage - "The seed of the woman shall Crus crush the serpents head," or in the time of Abraham who believed God and went out from his own country "not knowing whither he went," or even in the time of Christ when men said - "How long dost thou make

22
us to doubt? If thou be the Christ tell us plainly." Our day is ablaze with Gospel light. The accumulated facts of Centuries past reflect their rays at our feet, "and if men refuse to recognize the light and press with the owls and bats into the darkness their danger is only the more fearful."   Nor is it the past simply that presses responsibility upon us. Every new event, fulfilling prophecy; Every advance of Civilization; Every influx of knowledge; Every disentomed city that offers its sculptured testimonies

23
in conformation of the historic authenticity of the word of God; Every new discovery of science illustrating and confirming the system of revealed truth, every new translation of scriptures, making more accurate and clear the inspired word - all these impose a heavier condemnation on those who sin against so much light.   The increasing activity of the church in pressing the claims of X upon the consciences of men - and the strivings of the Holy Spirit convincing them of sin of righteousness and judgment also add

24
intensity to their peril. These are voices which echo the words of Christ - "If I had not come and spoken unto them they had not had sin, but now they have no cloak for their Sin." (next page) -

But there are Emergencies that are of a more special character; such as arise from social life in cities.

28
first sentence crossed out
The tendency of the race has ever been to congregate. Men would rather starve to death in a large City than to live in the country where there is abundance to eat & to wear. Cities have thus necessarily become the great Centres of Commerce, politics, Education and religion, and consequently places of Crisis and peril. Questions involving human welfare and destiny are there pressed for solution. Every thing is at high tide. Like the waves out at sea in conflict. Men grow swiftly in whatever direction their minds are bent. Formative influences are strong - If men harden

29

- They harden fast; if they mature a moral life it is with rapidity. City life makes great Christians and great reprobates at the same time. -

text on the rest of the page is crossed out

31
Then there are times when it would seem that public conscience has become paralyzed - Crime runs riot - Mischief is framed by a law. Transgressors have it their own way - Courts are a farce - officers are particep.  Crimimn's and the swollen tides of vice rush on without check until giant corruption treads down all our safeguards and our homes are despoiled of their Sacredness and harmony, and our children crushed beneath the heel of vice. Such times are often followed by financial disaster - panics - riots - bank failures. When the poor are without money and without work. Then it is that the

32
wreckers of society are out cruising for spoils. Drinking saloons plu..? themselves, and there is a swifter whirl and broader margin to every social maelstrom.  O the emergencies of Such times!. And who shall say that the Souls of men are not imperrilled as well as their business.   The Church itself is not an exceptional case. Its whole history has been one of crisis. There was never a time when it was not environed by some kind of Emergency. Its track from Eden to Calvary, and from Pentecost to the present has been marked by Exegency.

33
The expulsion of Adam - the murder of Abel - the deluge - the enslavement of Israel in Egypt - the Red Sea - the wanderings in the wilderness - the captivities - the death of X - the martyrdoms of the apostles & early disciples - the heresy of Rome - the darkness of the Middle Ages - the persecutions of the inquisition - the modern "ism's" of a ?.n?rted? gospel - and the specious attack of Satan as an angel of light - these same constituted the seeming peril of the Church - But along with them God has provided a way to Escape. His hand behind the Curtain, has been ready,

34
at the exact moment to touch the secret spring of providence which has brought deliverance in the extremity. Thus while Gods Zion has ever been upon the verge of some impending crisis it has also led on its ever increasing hosts from conquering to conquer. Each local Church has also its crises, when "now or never" would seem to be its only appropriate motto - when Effectual doors are opened, and if not entered then, will be forever shut against us. When many are asleep - when love has waxed cold. When personal responsibility has been laid aside - when personal

35
convictions of truth are yielded to the pressure of association and circumstance - When ease and popularity are sought instead of conscious burden bearing for X - We often hear the complaint that the Church is always in some kind of a straight, and because of it few want nothing to do with it. If they could belong to a church where there was no money to pay - no care to be exercised - no heart anxiety to be felt - no sacrifice and self-denial to be practiced, they would no doubt be happy - but they will never find such a Church on this Sin cursed planet. The Church of Jesus X on Earth was

36
never designed to be a feathered nest with a golden egg in it - nor a bed of do?? to go to heaven on. It was organized, Equipped and put on Earth to fight to meet emergencies - the moral crisis of men's souls - and when it is not our in open conflict, or in the trenches watching for the foe, or in the fortress defending its truth - it is in camp holding a counsil of war - Strengthening the faith of the wavering and planning for greater victories. No! My friends, so long as sin and holiness - the Church and the world are side by side the Covenant people of God will be in the midst of Emergency.

Nations also have their crises. These may not be independent of the destiny of the Kingdom and Church of X. They have often been linked together, when to save a nation was to perpetuate the Ch. The ancient Church was wrapped up in the destinies of the Hebrew nation. Esther was face to face with a national peril. While that case was exceptional, involving as it did the theocratic government, who shall say that in a very important sense the English Speaking Nations of today do not hold largely the destiny of the Kingdoms of X. Among these nations, America holds the foremost place of

responsibility. The fate of the nations is the fate of the Kingdom in it. You need not be told here today, as though it were new and strange, that this nations is confronting peril. There is terrible significance in the prophecy made years ago by Lord Macauley concerning the peril awaiting our nation. These are his startling words: As for America, I appeal to the 20" Century. Either some Caesar or Napoleon will seize the reins of Government with a strong hand or your Republic will be as fearfully

plundered and laid waste by barbarians in the 20" Century as the Roman Empire was in the 5" & with this difference, that the Huns and vandals who ravaged Rome came without her borders, while your Huns and vandals will be engendered within your own country, and by your own institutions. The institutions which contain the seeds of our national ruin, are already here. And they are multiplying at a fearful rate. They are destroying our health, muddling our brains, wasting

our resources, blasting our morals, sucking the heart blood of the nation, and putting the reins of power in the hands of political tricksters and red-handed villains. Rum rules the land & jubilant?  Nor is this all. Christianity is fast becoming a political crime. When Christian men organize for the suppression of this institution they become the object of the bitterest persecution even if they are not slaughtered. The Church of X is held at naught. The Sabbath is railed at as puritanic, and openly desecrated. This institution is training more forces and turning them loose against the Church in this country than the Church is supplying

for the conversion of the whole world. A political regeneration must take place soon or we be politically damned! peril to this nation carries with it peril to the Church - peril to missions and peril to untold millions of souls! And what adds intensity to this peril is the increasing light which men are constantly getting on this subject but which they will not heed. The liquor traffic is now concided to be the source of the most of our National woes. Therefore this is the condemnation of the Nation today that light has come? indicating the only successful line of action and men - voting men - do not walk politically - nor scientifically nor scripturally - in the light of the nature - and potency of this evil.

We have thus covered a wide range of circumstances and for the better purpose of showing how we are to behave ourselves under such conditions.
II  The great questions is __ who has come to the Kingdom for such a time as this?  The lessons from Esthers history furnish us with the divine philosophy as to how we are to meet similar Emergencies.

1. Esther was urged on to make her bold plea through a sense of her personal responsibility for her people. If deliverance were to come to them she knew it must be by her own intercession for them. It forcibly illustrates the awful prominence and responsibility

38
given to the individual as a depository of trust for others & Esther had a power which no one else could exercise. One evil heart sent out the decree; one pure heart must stay it. The destiny of thousands was poised on the course of one. So it has often been in the history of the Church and the nation. The individualism of the Bible is strikingly prominent. "In Adam all die." "Thro one man sin entered into the world" So "they who receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness shall reign in life by one, Jesus Christ".  The first Adam brought death into our world and all our wo - the Second Adam brought life and everlasting joy. The history of Noah, Abraham and Jacob illustrates how the whole

39
destiny of the Church has been at various times deposited in the person of one man. And though every man must bear his own burden yet he may also bear the family's burden - the City's burden or the nation's burden. That is not the true form of religion which tends to destroy the identity of the person. God does not speak to men in the mass - His promises - warnings - exhortations and gifts are to men as individuals. He deals with persons in time - and he will deal with persons in the judgment. The divine philosophy teaches us to act as if the whole world was dependent on each one of us for its salvation.

2. Esther held a peculiar relation both

41
to the King and to the condemned people. This was another secret of her success. They were her kindred and as Queen she had access to the King. God brings us into access with him not for purposes of enjoyment simply, but to avert the soul peril of kindred or friends which no one else can do. Every child of God is a mediator between the King and a lost world. The fact that you are converted and others in your household are not, means something. you have power at the throne which they have not. You know how to enter with your plea. power you possess even though deliverance to them shall finally come from another place.
3. In the third place Esther realised her dependance upon God. When she had resolved to undertake for her people she returned Mordecai this answer: "Go, gather together all the Jews and fast ye for me, and neither eat nor drink for three days night or day. I also and my maidens will fast, and so will I go in unto the King and if I perish, I perish." "So will I go."  With the assurance of prayer my friends, there is nothing more prominent in history than the efficacy of intercessory prayer for the averting

43
of threatening peril. It has entered as a necessary factor into the government of God. When all other hopes perish, all men believe enough in God and prayer to cry unto Him in the time of their troubles, whatever their pretensions may be at other times. The history of the Church would be broken into detached fragments were it not for the connecting links furnished by the intersessions of Gods people in times of crisis. There was Noah, called a "mighty intercessor" - Abraham pleading for sodom for the sake of ten righteous. - Moses standing in the breach between disobedient Israel and an offended God - The Church praying without Ceasing for Peter's

44
release from prison. There is no preparation for a great work or for anticipated ills like this. Even our Lord thought it necessary to fast 40 days before entering upon the trials of his public ministry, and as he drew near the great crisis of his life, yea, the crisis of a world - we see him in the garden bowed with his face to the ground - the blood pressing from his brow - while he cried - if it be possible let this cup pass from me.

The other story -

In his extreme old age he had to be carried to the Church. And being unable to deliver long discourses he simply said - "Little children love one another."  When asked by he repeated this so much he replied "Because this is the command of the Sacred, and enough is done if this is obeyed."  John died a natural death at the age of 90 yrs. or over.

*  Natural Pride

"Naturalists find it much less easy to teach a mountain flower to accommodate itself to a low locality than to get one which by birth belongs in the valleys to live and thrive at a lofty elevation. S earth    There seems to be nothing more difficult to men than to descent gracefully. How few who have been accustomed to a high position in Society are able to reconcile themselves to a humble one. So also it is with us in our low and lost estate. Spiritually poor, we are spiritually proud.  Saying "I am rich and increased in goods, & have need of nothing," while we are wretched and miserable and poor, and blind and naked. Indulging in pride out of all keeping "with filthy rags" we will not stoop to stand at Gods door, poor mendicants, who ask for mercy.

          Poor in Spirit

Oh, blessed poor, who more than Earth
Shall at Earth's close inherit!
Not squalid state, or abject birth,
Infolds this priceless merit.
Not weary wanderers of the street,
With haggard eyes & halting feet,
This heirship's strange conditions meet!
It reads: "The poor in Spirit."
________________
Yet Earthly rank, or low or high,
Sets to this class no limit,
Not boundless wealth can glorify -
Nor poverty can dim it!
It is the temper of the soul,
Strength in Humility's Control,
A life grace-moulded to its whole -
For angels to esteem it.

Theirs is a Kingdom Evermore
Of such transcendent glory,
Its rank and royalty before -
Fade the proud realms of story.
That, infinite in time and space
These, crowding each for narrow place;
That, ever young, though ages cease;
And these, how transitory!
____________
Kingdom of heaven, Kingdom of God,
Ineffable possession
Of those who lowly paths have trod
In life's unsummed procession -
The poor in spirit, dead to pride,
Who worthless hold worth unallied
With merit of the Crucified,
In life's and death's Confession!

There is a line by us unseen
That crosses every path
The hidden boundary between
Gods patience and his wrath.
___________________
To pass that limit is to die
To die as if by sleuth
It does not quench the beaming eye
Nor pale the glow of health
______________________
The Conscience may be still at ease
The spirits light and gay
That which is pleasing still may please
And care be thrust away
______________________________
But on that forehead God has set
Indelibly a mark
Unseen by man, for man, as yet
Is blind and in the dark

Indeed the doomed ones path below
May bloom as Eden bloomed. 
He did not, does not, will not know
Or feel that he is doomed.
He feels perchance that all is well
And every fear is calmed. 
He lives, he dies, he wakes in hell
Not only doomed but damned. 
O where is that mysterious bourn
By which our path is crossed
Beyond which God himself hath sworn
That he who goes is lost.

China Wedding Ceremony
Mr. & Mrs. J.M. Jennings -
 Dec 25 1885

Hear ye! hear ye! hear ye! Know all the people by this presence that the Ship has at last arrived - Anchored off the harbor of Chinatown - Suburb of Silver City. Peculiar Craft= Not a Pirate ship - nor tug boat - nor scow nor man of war - but a 6 masted Clipper.  20 years out - without coming in for repairs or inspection  So peculiar a history as to warrant brief description - About 20 years since in the City of Davenport - there lived a man whose name was John - There was also a Weaver? maid whose name was Melissa - Now it came to pass that this same John fell to cogitating as to his helpless & woe begone condition, wherefore he at last discovered the secret of that peculiar goneness which gentlemen in his condition usually experience. He remembered that there had been taken from his Adamic constitution

by a peculiar surgical operation a rib evermore called woman which had never been resupplied. So he begins a clever search for the loved & lost - He finds plenty of the article but not the identical rib. The poet has said - When Eve brot woe to all mankind &c. but this matter was no whim to him. At last he found his match - in Melissa. & was made whole & happy. He applied to one Watson - a parson who did the Splicing. Then the journey of life began & being of baptistic notions they proposed to go by water & so took ship - named "The John M. Jennings" - Having a eye to business they took no cruise for pleasure but started right out on the  main trip down the River of time. John Capt. - pilate -, His rib 1st Mate & mess Mate. Their experiences were not unlike those of  others who get into such a boat. They passed by rocks. Shoals. thro Straights, against head winds & contrary winds.  Sometimes in calm & sometimes "half seas over" - Occasionally took on an extra sail - & whereas they had only two at first they have since put out 4 little Sheets to the wind. And now after 20 years of Storm & Shine - without dropping anchor they put into the pop-port & have entered the dry dock for repairs - to replenish their wares

and especially for careful inspection as to whether the reach and strain of the ship has damaged the splicing or whether after the lapse of as many years there are evidence of decay where parts were joined together. I will now proceed with such inspection:  John, did you take Melissa 20 yrs ago to be your lawful & wedded wife? "I did" Have you  loved her? "I have". Have you paid all the bills she has contracted without complaint? "Ask her." Melissa. Did you take John & c. "I did". Have you loved him? "I have". Have you obeyed him? ___  Have you vexed his righteous soul day by day as all good housewives do? "I presume I have." I am satisfied. If any person present knows of any reason why this ship should not go on her way let him now speak or else hereafter hold his tongue.

In token of your shifted?? and continued affection & mutual satisfaction with other as companions in life you will please to join your right hands promising anew each the other to love cherish & keep &c.
I do no in the presence of these witnesses your friends pronounce you in a safe & sound condition, ready to proceed on your journey. and what hath been so well joined together let no man put assunder. In addition to these allusions your friends are gathered here tonight especially to congratulate you on your successful & happy passage thus far & to bid you a hearty God Speed on your way toward the harbor of eternal rest.
Prayer
Congratulations-

Address at the "Commencement" of the Home Mission Training School Chicago - 1886
It is with great pleasure that I represent the pastor department of work in the Training School on this occasion. The humble part which I have been permitted to take in this work during the last 4 years has been exceedingly pleasant. I have never engaged in Christian work which has given me greater satisfaction or in which I have been more conscious of the approval of my Master. This school has come, to my mind, preemintly,

2

the Shrine Stamp? from the beginning. Gods providential hand has been distinctly seen in establishing guiding, prospering and enlarging the work up to the present-time. No one could have foretold from the first the large measure of success which this enterprise has achieved. The Secret is not because of energy and zeal and human skill which have been brought into service but because the work has had a divine and Scriptural foundation. let me guide your thought along this line for a few moments.

3           

Let me say to these young women who go out from us tonight for their comfort and assurance
1. You fill a divine Office. It is not an office created by the Woman's Board, or by human devising. It is nothing called into existence by the demands of these latter times and tacked on as a Supplement to the Scriptural plan. You will find your office designated distinctly in the word of God. We are told in the Acts that there was in the Church at Antioch - that first Missionary Church - "Certain prophets and teachers."

4

Paul said to the Corinthians that "God hath set some in the Church first - Apostles. Secondly prophets, thirdly teachers." And again to Timothy - "The things that thou hast heard of me by many witnesses the same commit thou to faithful men who shall be able to teach others also." I do not believe we have outgrown the Bible plan of saving the world - or the Bible plan of conducting Christian enterprises. There is no work demanded of us in this age that cannot be best accomplished through the

5

medium of some office clearly defined in Gods word. This, then, is to be your stamp and comfort - You fill a divine Office.
2. To this Office you have received a divine call. I believe a divine office requires a divine call to fill it. The evidence of your call you will find in your own consciousness. in the providential circumstances which have led you - in the judgment of those who know you best. and in the demands of the work to which you go -  God forbid that you should step into Such an office without His approval. And should this prove to be the

6

case you will very soon find it out. The work to which you go will "Sift you as wheat." and you will soon find that you have "run without being sent." But I trust that this will not prove true in the case of any one of you. The Board - the pastors and teachers who have been with you in the class room think they see the divine Land resting before you.
3. For such a work you need a divine qualification  A divine office filled by a divine call requires a divine qualification  God gave Moses an office called him to it and prepared him for it.

(1) This appears. Clearly enough from the nature of the work you will have to do.  I have not the time nor

7

is this the place to particuliarize - but in general if I have any correct idea about it, you must be prepared to do anything necessary to be done - No one can tell you beforehand just what you may be called upon to do - You must be all things to all Men. Esp. a teacher - 

 a teacher to parents  
 a teacher to children
 a teacher to preachers
a teacher to teachers, and an adviser in general. You are sent also as a Citizen to conserve the public morals, a Miss'y to gather, instruct convert and edify.

8

2. What are the qualifications necessary for such a work.   Let me mention four on which I wish to lay special emphasis - and these are the ones which it is the purpose of your course in the Training School to develop in you.

(1) Divine fellowship -    It is a primary object of this School to lead its pupils into a close fellowship with Christ - and a reliance on Him in all things. It is the highest compliment to be paid to any Christian institution that

9

to say that the Spirit of God is there. And just this may be said of our Training School. The habit of taking all our concerns unto God for His decision or approval - Seeking His guidance in little things as well as great is a necessary qualification for a Missionary teacher. You will find this intimate relation to Christ necessary to give you the right Spirit and temper of mind with which to do your work. You will need it for spiritual discrimination in detecting the right from the wrong, and especially,

10                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                10

for your own comfort. You will see dark days. The time will come when if you have not the conscious presence of Christ - if you have not the habit of casting your care upon Him you will sit down in despair.  But this is not all that you need.
(2) A second qualification is grounding in the faith. Spiritual fellowship is not everything - God did not design it to be. The comfort of the Holy Ghost will not take the place of knowledge but must be linked to it.

11

"What God hath joined together let not man put asunder" applies to some things other than the marriage relation. Faith & works go together - also zeal and knowledge. Life and doctrine   Woe be unto us if we be the means of divorcing these great instrumentalities of the Gospel. The day is past when a limp covered Bible a few pious platitudes reinforced by a gush of enthusiasm will convert men or even attract their attention. It is an age of inquiry when all classes are asking the reason for things.

12

The Bible will answer all necessary questions if you will give it a chance. Paul said "the things which ye have heard of Me - the same comment to faithful men who shall be able to teach others also."  Christ said "Ye shall know the truth and the truth shall make you free." You will meet superstitions and perversions of the truth which will be difficult to meet except you know your Bible.   But if there is a reason why any Missionary teacher should be grounded in the faith- there is a special

13

reason why a Baptist Missionary should be so. A Baptist is nothing unless he is a Bible man. He is a Baptist because the Bible makes him so. A Baptist Missionary can make little progress without being able to give a reason for his faith. The aim of your course has been to make you sound in doctrine - and in Baptist doctrine
(3) A third qualification is Intelligence as to Methods  It is one thing to know what to do - it is quite another thing to know how to do it.  In your work you will find that the means and the methods will be important factors in your success. An important part of your training has been to learn how to do work to the best advantage -

14

Lastly - The Spirit of faithfulness is an essential qualification.   Remember that Paul told Timothy to commit these things to "faithful men". What did he mean? He evidently used it in
a broad sense - as faithful to yourselves - ie; to your minds, bodies, souls. Faithful in all your preparations for your work, and thorough in doing it, faithful in your example.   Be what you want others to be. Faithful to others whether they will hear or forebear.  You will be tempted to compromise when you ought not. and when you should  "Rebuke, exhort, with all long suffering and doctrine."

15

Faithful to the word. You can not improve upon it  Trust it and it will do the work. And then faithful at all times - in the darkness as well as in the light. It is all light with God. Faithful when things go well and faithful when they go ill. We may not be able to do great, and brilliant things for God but we all can be faithful. And remember that He does not hold us accountable so much for results as He does for faithfulness. He will take care of the results and at last He will say "Well done thou good and faithful servant. Enter thou unto the joy of the Lord."
